response.answer_text: Specific answer, involving much scientific wildass guessing but also a lot of fun not included in the "General answer" at bottom here: Stage 1: We'll accept genetic cures for a few major illnesses, the low-hanging fruit of gene therapy, as we've already started to do for certain leukemias in early human trials that are dizzying in their success rates. Stage 2.1: We'll soon see full genome sequencing doable in minutes at a cost of tens or hundreds of US dollars.   Stage 2.2a: We'll enact laws ensuring strangers go to jail for sequencing our genomes against our will. Stage 2.2b: We'll start paying people to sequence their genomes.  Who's we?  Medical research facilities, and health insurance companies. Stage 3:  We'll start knowing in much greater detail what genetic markers have what impact on our longterm disease rates and longevity.  Why?  Because of our massive database of individual human genomes (cross-correlated with personal and family medical histories) as described in the previous step, combined with ever advancing computing power that brings us closer and closer to understanding gene interactions and protein folding. Stage 4: Genome sequencing will be essentially free.  US insurance companies will have most citizens' genomes on file, despite the laws, because when information can be had from a stray hair, and for almost free, who can trace its provenance? And these insurers will strain to eject genetic "bad apples" from their coverage system.  Legislation will enter a new phase of socioeconomic, public-vs-industry war that will make ObamaCare/ACA look like a happy memory.   Stage 5: US insurance companies will realize that genetic cures and preventative gene therapies are the only affordable way to cover patients who are otherwise doomed to bankrupt said insurers.  Gene therapies will proliferate as the path of least resistance through this massive health insurance armageddon of total genomic knowledge vs the very notion of insurance as a buffer against uncertainty.   Stage 6: Most patients will face choices between accepting gene therapies and paying for future or present medical conditions out of pocket.  Most patients will choose gene therapies.  Culture will rage about this on a scale that makes modern worries about vaccines and GMOs look placid.  Stage 7.1: People will screen their unborn children for a vast number of genetic markers and therapy their embryos and fetuses for same, both in vitro and in vivo. Stage 7.2: People will also select their unborn children for traits we've evolved to want: Beauty (symmetry and proportionality), muscle mass, high metabolism, reflexes, endurance, height, full hair, and so on.  Intellect will play a role, but will be limited, as it always has been, by the burdens our big craniums put on pregnant women, and on our spines. Stage 8: The fun stuff: Some people will start selecting their children not for traits we're hardwired to like, but for traits that actually confer success in the actual world their children are being born into.  Namely, we'll start seeing children born not to look like Greek gods, but who look like gray aliens.  Eyes that see a fuller EM spectrum, organs near the eyes that function like an fMRI to see into other people's heads and manipulate same.  Children whose digestive systems have been replaced by a simplified energy battery.  Photographic memories with 100x the capacity of other brains.  Spatial reasoning centers capable of thinking in 4+ spatial dimensions.  Muscles not made of muscle, that are stronger than muscle without any of the curb appeal.  Bones that never shatter, that are stronger than human bone and lighter and would sooner bend than break.  Endogenous organelles in the brain that allow for direct information transfer with other brains or machines. Mouths vestigial.  Giant heads held aloft by these new bones and muscles, freed from the constraints to which previous human heads were subject.  Multiple sight organs aligned in bands reflecting the various parts of the EM spectrum each one covers, with each band covered by a black carapace.  Structures that previously protected us from fighting injuries, like sturdy eyesockets, brow ridges, cheekbones, nose bridges, and lantern jaws, vanished.  And hair abandoned as an obsolete sign of health and method for regulating body temperature. Basically, A new crop of kids will rise up who look like the gal at the top of this answer. What, you thought that was a male? Be nice, this is your great-granddaughter we're talking about!  :) Stage 9.1:  Those kids scare the shit out of people who aren't little gray aliens. Stage 9.2: Those kids and their parents use their advantages to ensure they're not pogrommed into oblivion, which also will involve them securing a lot of wealth or power for themselves. Stage 10: Other people realize they either make their offspring have some of the same traits as the little alien weirdos, or their offspring will be second-class citizens, in fact will be a different and subservient species to the weirdos. Stage 11:  We're a new species.   General answer, in which I am much more confident: Evolution is change via evolutionary algorithm.  So if we just manually change our own genes or augment ourselves with machinery, that is not evolution per se.   But if we really are about to embark on a great experiment in modifying ourselves both by gene and by machine, we might soon discover that the best modifications are found through the aid of evolutionary algorithms, rather than straight old fashioned engineering and design.   So let's say that happens.  Evolutionary algorithms can be tweaked to solve problems beyond the basic one in nature, "Which variety of things can keep existing in this environment?"  They can be tweaked almost at will.  So, will humans evolve themselves to handle pollution?  Entirely possible.  Will humans evolve nature to deal with pollution before it reaches our bodies?  Entirely possible.  Will humans evolve themselves to conform to old ideas of environmental fitness, hardwired into our brains and evident on the cover of every magazine?  Super duper possible. And let's say somehow we *don't* do any genetic engineering on ourselves.  Evolution will still eventually happen.  According to the latest estimates, separated populations will diverge into separate species every 50,000 generations to 100,000 generations.  That also implies with a little bit of inference that after 2 million years a single species could not reproduce with its ancestors from 2 million years earlier.  And this is an average. Like the average speed of the water in a river, there are places where the water almost stands still and places where it rushes faster.   If this seems without evidence, please understand that the evidence for it involves the genes and bones and bodies and gravesites of many many different species. If you want a simpler analogy, think about how language changes over time. It is usually possible for someone to understand a speaker of their "same" language from 200 years ago but not from 1000 years ago and definitely not from 2000 years ago.  That is how language evolves, and genes evolve the same way only 1000 times more slowly.

There is no way to estimate what evolution will do to H. sapiens because we cannot know what future environments will be like.  However, I do not think you have considered how difficult it is to make evolutionary changes in large populations.  Whenever any species has a large population that is well-adapted to the environment, it is very difficult for any evolutionary change in that population.  It is the "stasis" part of punctuated equilibrium. For there to be an "evolutionary step" as you are thinking of it, a new allele, or combination of alleles (forms of genes) needs to spread to the entire population.  Evolutionary biologists speak of the "effective population" N, which is the number of individuals who can breed (for sexually reproducing organisms).  Even under severe selection, it takes at least 0.5 N generations for a trait to spread through the population. The total human population is about 7 billion.  Let's be conservative and say that only 4 billion are capable of breeding, with 50% male and 50% female.  A generation is 20 years.  With the current human population, 0.5 N = 2 billion and with a 20 year generation time that is 40 billion years for any trait to become fixed!  The entire species H. sapiens is not changing soon! An implication for this is that population sizes for H. sapiens were much, much less in the past.   And that is the case.  This paper -- http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1832099/ -- estimates the effective population size to be 3100 to 7500 for most of the history of H. sapiens.  This paper -- http://www.pnas.org/content/111/2/757.full.pdf -- estimates that the effective population size has been about 10,000 people until about 140 generations ago.

There is a great deal of confusion about "evolution".  It is an unfortunately chosen word, to say the least.  Darwin spoke of "survival of the fittest", which is far better, and a complete phrase would be "survival of the fittest through procreation". There is actually no such thing as "evolution".  The word conjures up images of species becoming better, improving.  This was never the implication according to Darwin.  His term "natural selection" provides a better hint.  The key here is that statistically, in a given species and under given circumstances, certain genetic anomalies may cause particular members of a species to be better disposed to survive through procreation.  There is certainly chance involved, in two ways.  Firstly, genetic mutation results purely as a result of errors in the genetic copying process when eggs / sperm are generated.  Secondly, survival to procreation obviously has a great deal of chance involved, especially when procreation happens at the age of 14+ as is typically the case in humans. Next important factor.  Humans no longer have any significant natural enemies.  Sure, there is disease to some minor degree, but in most first-world areas the mortality as a result of disease is at a rate so low that it is pretty much insignificant. This last means that in any population of humans living in first-world conditions, there is no significant selective pressure.  Any number of these humans who choose to will be able to breed.  Selection for procreation amongst humans has become an issue of conscious choice, not one of survival. Long story short - there is no selective pressure on the majority of the human population.  We are not "evolving" and have not done so for a very, very long time. The correct answer to your question : There is no next major step.   There is no evolution.  We are a species at the end of our selective existence, unless circumstances change dramatically at some point in the future. A modifier on the above, just for fun.  The largest "selective" pressure being exerted on the first-world human population at present is due to the conscious decision to have few if any children by large numbers of humans falling in certain demographic categories.  I will leave the reader to contemplate the dominant characteristics of these humans.  They are being selected (are selecting themselves) for progressive extinction.   The humans still choosing not to limit progeny under most circumstances are being selected for survival.  Draw your own conclusions.

response.answer_text: The next major step in the evolution of the human species will be the creation of a new, more cognitively advanced species.For the majority of humanity's existence, the forces affecting to the sophistication of our cognition have been primarily external to our bodies. In other words, our technologies and cultures have been the implements making the human population "smarter," not major physiological changes to our brains, themselves.  The big exception to this "rule" was the development of language, which may have happened in part as a result of sudden and dramatic downward pressure on the human population some 50,000-70,000 years ago. Whatever caused it, the development of language radically altered the cognitive destiny of homo sapiens sapiens. Trading systems, significantly more sophisticated tools and rich cultural practices all descended from our new ability to talk. It was literally the dawn of our species in its modern form.  My guess is that in our lifetimes or our children's lifetimes (much more if global civilization collapses first), humanity will start to see the beginnings of another shift that will be as profound as that one – a literal evolution of our internal cognitive capacities. I suspect that this shift will arise from the merging of computers + the internet with our brains.  The seeds of this massive overhaul are already being planted (implanted?) in monkeys and cognitively crippled humans. There are (very rudimentary) implantable brain-computer interfaces that allow people who can't speak to type out simple messages with the power of their thoughts alone. If you extrapolate that technology along a large enough horizon, you get to brains that can talk to the internet and an internet that can talk back to brains. If the world's mad scientists figure out how to safely and effectively implement internet-enabled brains, it's safe to say that the resulting animals wouldn't qualify as Homo sapiens sapiens anymore. Indeed, the differences between us and them would be as stark as those between pre-humans and humans. They would be post-human in every sense of the term.

Now, what I think could possibly occur is we might start doing artificial selection on our species or bioengineering/genetic engineering ourselves.   At a very simple level, people are already doing this.  There are groups such as the Fertility Institutes ( http://www.gender-selection.com/?gclid=CO241JaH-JgCFRxNagodVX7DnAthat ) that allow people to screen in vitro generated embryos to make sure the ones that get implanted do not have genetic diseases, and pick things like gender, etc.  Other companies such as gene security networks (Gene Security Network in race for prenatal test - San Francisco Business Times ) will allow couples to easily screen naturally conceived fetuses for genetic diseases.   If these type of technologies become more main stream, you may see increased selective pressure against deleterious recessive alleles, say if the parents choose not only to screen out homozygotes recessive embryos but heterozygous carrier embryos as well.  Of course these technologies will most likely only be available for the wealthy.  At this point I am getting into non-scientific speculation, but given enough time I wonder if there might be a divide between rich and poor not just in the distribution of wealth but the distribution of genetic fitness as well. For example, science can currently give monkeys that only have two color receptors a third color receptor, effectively taking color blind monkeys and giving them the ability to see in the full range of colors that non-color blind humans can see (Gene Therapy Cures Color-Blind Monkeys | Wired Science | Wired.com) .  Now humans have 3 color receptors, but some birds have 4 and can see in the UV spectrum.  Could we engineer humans that could see in the UV spectrum?  It's not that far fetched,  even with current technologies. What might future technologies allow for? I doubt humans will change at all through NATURAL selection anytime in the near future, but some subset of humans might be changed through artificial selection (ie genetic screening) or synthetic biology (bio/genetic engineering) applied to our species.

Human evolution: there are a few trends in reproduction which will likely produce an noticeable overall change in the world's population within the next few hundred years. The tendency for educated, working mothers is: delayed conception, fewer offspring, more cesarean deliveries, and a greater likelihood of mating with a male who is genetically distant. As for the offspring produced in developed countries, we are seeing more autism, auto-immune diseases, obesity and taller children. Skin color is moving away from the extremes and toward medium pigmentation--mostly as a result of increased genetic variety in matings as immigration increases and cultural taboos fall by the wayside. Microbial evolution: the outstanding selective pressure on infectious microbes is the medical community's overuse of antibiotics. The exposure of bacteria that live in, on and around patients in hospitals to a wide range of antibiotics year after year is gradually (some people would say rapidly) leading to the development of strains of multiple antibiotic resistant bacteria such as the infamous Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). A similar selective pressure also affects eukaryotic parasites. The four species of the malaria parasite Plasmodium which affect humans are becoming resistant to chloroquine and other key antimalarial drugs. Much the same situation exists with resistant organisms that cause plant disease. Aquatic organisms: with influences such as warming temperatures, overfishing, oxygen depletion, acidification and effluent (sewage and runoff); marine and fresh water species of all types are finding their environment dramatically changed. The resulting trend is toward reduced diversity and increased microbial life. None of the above will directly result in an evolutionary change for a particular species, per se, until the selective pressure(s) provide an advantage for genetically mutated individuals to survive while the wild type (un-mutated) population dies off. That is, unless one considers extinction as an example of evolutionary change, in which case the next step in evolution will be achieved when the next endangered species disappears from the Earth. Sorry to be so negative, but nature is bloody in tooth and claw. There is a great deal more to discuss on this topic...the above is a start.

If humankind keeps evolving its non-natural processes, technologies and knowledge, there won’t be any significant pressure for a “next step” in evolution. Ironically, the more we evolve in the social development and technological progress of our society, the less we’re likely to evolve significantly in the next thousands of years, or rather we should say that the more likely it is that the evolution of our species will become extremely slow compared with those species that, unlike in our “man-made world”, depend entirely on the natural environment and their stricly biological adaptations. If we manage to avoid any big disaster or social-economic kickback, I’d expect the next big steps for humankind to come not from natural selection and evolution, but from artificial processes, perhaps even including some meddling into our genome to eliminate certain genetic tendencies to disease or other unfavorable characteristics. Physically, as a species, though, my expectation and also my hope is that the natural pressures of evolution - which inevitably involve the massive death of all those who aren’t fit enough for the new environmental conditions - will be much reduced, and we’ll see only minor changes, for the better or for the worse, even in a very long period of 100,000 years or even more than that. Just consider that, even when we lived as simple hunter gatherers exposed to the many changes of the world (including severe Ice Ages!), we have still evolved only in slightly discrete respects in the last 200,000 years and, particularly, in the last 50,000 years. And that was before modern science and technologies reduced our death rate from an average 4–5% every year to just 0.5–1.0% per year.

Excellent question. I’m going to give you what I expect will be a rather contentious answer. First off, forget biological evolution. Human beings are still evolving to better suit our current, decidedly unnatural environment, but that evolution is no longer very effective in terms of shaping the nature of our species. For one thing, we have managed to neutralize the process of natural selection. The vast majority of the people now live long enough to procreate many times over, regardless of their fitness for survival. In terms of the human condition, that’s an outstanding achievement. But it’s catastrophic for the mechanism that brought us to this point. Second, to the extent that evolution is still at work on our species, it is simply too slow to have any real impact given the pace of change in today’s technological world. Put these two factors together, and biological evolution is essentially irrelevant to the future of our species. Fortunately, a new kind of evolution has taken its place: cultural evolution. The tenets of human cultures are transmitted across generations, not unlike genes, but they are subject to change within the lifetime of an individual. So, even though our brains are still grounded in our evolutionary habitat of the savanna, the way we think and communicate are changing rapidly. So the question really becomes: What is the next step in *cultural* evolution. I truly wish I knew the answer to that question. Here’s the good news: The shift to cultural evolution means the future of our species is entirely in our own hands. We have become, in a very real sense, our own creators. Unfortunately, that’s also the bad news. Our forager brains, with their deeply rooted me-and-my-tribe survival instincts, simply don’t equip us for tackling problems on a global scale. Think about it. There are seven and a half billion of us on this planet today, and in less than 35 years that number will jump to ten billion. Supporting this many people in the style to which we’ve all become accustomed (or are striving to achieve) is taxing the planet beyond its limits. Being a member of the “duck and cover” generation, I always figured that the greatest danger to our species was thermonuclear war, but it now seems to me that we’ll probably just suck our planet dry of its natural resources before we can make the leap to other planets. Now comes the most contentious part. I think cultural evolution could take is in an entirely new and much more durable direction. I’m talking about the leap from flesh and blood to silicon and steel. If we didn’t live in such fragile shells with such demanding environmental requirements, we could easily be in space already and colonizing planets that could never support organic forms of life. With our feet now woefully incapable of grasping even the smallest branches, evolution has taken steps to rid us of our smallest fifth toe.Whereas our other toes – especially the biggest – serve to aid balance and walking, our little toes serve no purpose, and humans can get by very well without them. Because of this, and because of the problems which arise from its needless existence – being frequently crushed in shoes and stubbed on every prominent object, to name a couple – we can expect humans to eventually evolve into a four-toed creature. Whether this is literal self-improvement, via bionic organs for example, or through gene selection, which has prospective parents choose their child’s traits before birth, this is the most likely avenue human evolution will take in the near future. The human brain, being a machine striving for maximum efficiency, typically remembers where information is stored, rather than the information itself. How many times have you tried to remember something, and instead simply looked up the answer? That’s your brain remembering where something is stored – on the internet, on google, on wikipedia, and so on. As technology becomes more and more advanced, our brains will adapt in order to maximize efficiency – perhaps to the detriment of our memory.  5)Increased Height-Human height has been growing rapidly for the last two centuries. Over the last 150 years alone, the average height of the species has increased by 10cm. It is believed that the main driving force behind this growth is the abundance of nutrition available to many of us. Famine has long been a curse for those aspiring to tallness – and in certain parts of the world, it has almost been eradicated.The more a child has to eat, the more energy he or she has to grow. As long as we have the ability to eat in excess, the species will continue to grow taller. Whether the sky is the limit, or whether biology will stop us short somewhere among the tree-tops, only time – and evolution – will tell.   and there could be a lot of other changes as well but who knows.I guess we just have to wait and watch!

The divine as a whole is eternal (Parmenides) or everlasting (Heraclitus), and unchanging; in respect of its parts it is subject to temporal process and change. For Heraclitus the account (logos) of the real is everlastingly true and describes a world that, despite constant change in respect of its parts, yet is one that is fundamentally a whole or unity, and as such a whole or unity everlasting. The account in question is not his own, except derivatively, but rather that being uttered everlastingly by the real itself and comprehended by the individual who takes the trouble to learn its language. Elsewhere Heraclitus suggests strongly that it is this real – in all its apparently divergent aspects – that is in fact the Divine [source of wisdom]. For Parmenides, likewise, the divine is knowable, but again it is only the divine as a totality [pan] which is so knowable, not a divine which is putatively fragmented. This divine as a whole is, as it is for Heraclitus, without beginning or end and changeless as such. The true account which describes this real is again derivatively that of Parmenides himself, but at base it is, analogously to that being uttered everlastingly by Heraclitus’ “divine” universe, the account propounded by a divinity, who in propounding it is also thereby the guarantor of its truth. For both philosophers there is only one route that can possibly be followed if knowledge of the real is to be attained. Pokémon is not in any way an accurate representation of biological evolution. There's no such thing as a "stage" of evolution and there certainly is no set sequence of stages that humans are going to go through.  We could go extinct, we could split into multiple daughter species, we could change significantly while remaining one population, or we could stay roughly the same, like horseshoe crabs. These are almost* all of the options available to any species.  *Humans can't form hybrids with closely related species, since our sufficiently close relatives are extinct.

Evolution uses genetic changes to select for those changs that make the species better suited to the niche it fills.  If there's no genetic change, we just have genetic drift - tiny changes that take mnillions of years to show large physical changes. Dinisaurs lived in a worls perfectly suited for them for about 135 million years.  There were changes in species, in genus, but the dominant life form was dinosaurid for 135 million years.  There was no pressure, and no empty niches, so there was no reason for anything to change.  When they were almost all wiped out (the ones that survived are called birds today) there were all sorts of open niches, that were mostly filled by mammals that fit them best.  But some mammals fit better than others of their species, so evolutionary pressure forced the species in that direction. If there aren't any genetic changes, or any changes in available niches, we can expect man to be around in his current form, with slow drift over the entire species, for a very long time.  (We won't speciate into two or more different species unless we travel to the stars, and some colony loses contact with the rest of the species for an evolutionarily long time.)
